description:
Journey to the underdark, a land teaming with cruelty and betrayal. The denizens of the underdark may be friend, foe, or just another creature looking for a warm-blooded meal.
The adventurers recently freed enslaved sverfneblin. These small, intelligent creatures were enlisted to create powerful weapons...and they succeeded. Taken from their homeland, they long to return, uncertain what they will find.

This campaign uses the 4th edition core rules for combat and character generation. I have adopted some of the 5th ed rules that prove more creativity and flexibility for both the players and the DM. Feel free to bring characters from other editions, just be aware or willing to adapt your character to fit 4th ed.

Characters are at 5th level. There is room for a couple players. We have a regular group of 4 to 5 depending.
name: Dungeons & Dragons

description:
For information on trip price, itinerary, pickup locations and all other details, please click here. Please note that you MUST book your seat and pay for it through the ShortTrips.ca website.

Please join us on this terrific once a year opportunity for an extra long 5-hour spring time cruise aboard the MS Chi Cheemaun on Georgian Bay along the coast of the spectacular Bruce Peninsula.

As many of you know, the Chi-Cheemaun ferry normally transports passengers every day in the summer months between Tobermory and Manitoulin Island. It's winter home however is Owen Sound! Today we will be boarding the ferry on its very first sailing of the year as it moves from Owen Sound to Tobermory. Our bus will drop us off at the dock in Owen Sound and pick us up at the end of the cruise in Tobermory.

A lovely hot & cold lunch buffet is included with the tour price. The cash bar will be open for refreshments. Music will be playing throughout the boat. What better way to enjoy the spring breezes than from the deck of a boat on Georgian Bay while sipping your favourite brew!

What's Included?

• Round trip transportation from the Toronto area on deluxe highway motor coach.

• One way 5-hour cruise ticket aboard the MS Chi-Cheemaun included.

• Hot & Cold buffet on board the boat included. Cash bar is available for soft drinks and alcoholic beverages.

• Complimentary water and snacks on the bus included. 

• All tips included. HST extra.

I hope you will join us on this fun day out and I hope to see you on the trip! 

- Sash

This trip is being arranged by:

Marville Travel Ltd.  
(905)[masked]  
TICO #[masked]

For information on trip price, itinerary, pickup locations and all other details, please click here. Please note that you MUST book your seat and pay for it through the ShortTrips.ca website.

description:
How it works

Would you like to learn how to play tennis in a social friendly group? It's great exercise and fun.

If we have sufficient RSVPs (4 days before we play) we will have an instructor otherwise, we will have a session of tournaments and drills/skills sessions.

When we do have a coach s/he will be experienced, qualified and exceptionally talented in their field.

Session will cost 10 euro per hour. We are likely to have the courts for 2 hours and you will have a minimum of one hour and a maximum of 2 hours on court training/playing. Mild cardio exercises may be interwoven. If you RSVP we really need you to come along. The first few mins may be devoted to warm-up exercises.

Types of technique practiced with a coach present

• Stance and split step

• Forehand cross court

• Back hand cross court

• Forehand down the line

• Backhand down the line

• Lobs

• Volleys

• Smashes

• Ground strokes

• Serves

Special Offer - you can get 20% off 1 to 1 lessons if you have a Dublin Tennis members card.

Note: As detailed in the notes issued to Dublin Tennis Members. If RSVPs are not sufficient (Decision made on Wednesday 12 midday) the session not have a coach. Reasoning: We have to pay a coach and give advance warning (coach is unlikely to travel across for only one session).

description:
Tickets are advance purchase Ticket Link:  http://uncorkeddenver-foppiano-warwick.eventbrite.com

What: Foppiano Portfolio Wine Tasting with Highly rated wines (90+) from the esteemed Northern California winemaker Louis Foppiano on the beautfiul patio at the Warwick (yeah...the place with the Playboy Twist!)  We will be sampling wines from Louis Foppiano's Sonoma Vineyard

We will be on the patio weather permitting.  If there is cold, snow rain/wind we will be INSIDE Randolph's

Where: Warwick Hotel in a private patito wine and food pairing at Randolphs in the place famous for the Playboy Club. 1776 Grant Street Denver, CO 80203 www.warwickdenver.com FREE VALET PARKING

Crowd: Young/Mid Professionals  (Most of our crowd is 30's to 50's but everyone is welcome to our winemaker events.

When: Tuesday April 7, 2015  Please be prompt as we will be serving each wine and appetizer paired

Dress: Dressy Casual/Dress to Impress

Cost: $ 29.99 includes tax and tip (Wine Party Only)   Tickets are advance purchase Ticket Link:  http://uncorkeddenver-foppiano-warwick.eventbrite.com

Dress: Business/Dressy Casual to Business/Dress to Impress

Wines and Food Pairing  TBA

Accolades/ratings of wines  http://www.foppiano.com/in-the-news

Founded in 1896 by Giovanni Foppiano, Foppiano Vineyards is one of Sonoma County's oldest continually-operated, family-owned wineries. Our family has supplied northern California with wine for over a century, surviving Prohibition in the 1920s by selling home winemaking kits.

Louis Foppiano is 4th generation and grew up in the winemaking business.  Over the years, Louis has worked in just about every position at the winery: driving the tractor in the vineyards; working the bottling line, crush pad and fermenting tanks; and, later after graduating from college, representing the winery around the world through sales and marketing.

Like the three generations before him, Louis Foppiano has set the simple goal of creating honest, consistent, high quality wines, which are meant to be enjoyed at the table with family and friends. Under his direction, Foppiano Vineyards has enjoyed great success, increased prosperity, and critical acclaim.

ASSUMPTION OF RISK - WAIVER AGREEMENT http://www.meetup.com/denverwine/pages/ASSUMPTION_OF_RISK_-_WAIVER_AGREEMENT
name: 90+ Pt Sonoma Patio Wine Party: Louis Foppiano@Warwick-Pl­­ayboy Twist!

description:
Hi All! Join me for another opportunity to see and support small regional theater groups at a reasonable price. The Campbell Theater in Martinez is putting on “The Foursome”. The Campbell Theater is located in Downtown Martinez and the tickets are $18.00 each at the theater or $9.00 each plus service charge on GoldStar. I have chosen the March 14,[masked]:00pm show. The theater is general admission, first come, first choice, no reserved seats, so if we want to sit together we should all enter at the same time. Let’s meet in front of the theater at 7:30pm.

This show is for the guys or the golf fans among us: Bring on the Golf Jokes.........

Noting that her husband looked more haggard and disgruntled than usual after his weekly golf game, his wife asked what was wrong.

He answered, "Well, on the fourth hole, Harry had a heart attack and died. It was terrible! The entire rest of the day, it was hit the ball, drag Harry, hit the ball, drag Harry.

The synopsis of the play is below.

The Foursome

A quartet of college buddies celebrate their school reunion with a round of golf, giving them a chance to catch up and crack wise, in this comedy at Martinez's Campbell Theatre. As they play the course and compare their accomplishments, the members of The Foursome boast and bust each others' balls easily enough. But soon, the cracks begin to show, and real truths start to emerge. Well-reviewed for its wit and insight into men and middle age, the play was written by acclaimed Canadian playwright Norm Foster.

Pay at the door on Saturday, March 14, 2015 at 7:30pm or purchase your tickets on Goldstar for $9.00 plus a service charge.

Martinez Campbell Theater 636 Ward Street, Martinez, CA
name: Let's Do & See "The Foursome"

An Afterwork drink for working professionals is a refreshing opportunity to see who is out there. It's nice to have this chance to go out, have fun and meet people, It's a wonderful way to network and socialise.

After a busy day at work, let's Meet, Mingle, Network, Party, Dance, and have some fun with other working professionals. Let us make some new personal and professional connections.

“Camels or working professionals cannot go for a week without a drink”

So if you are looking to destress, socialise and rejuvenate, here is what is happening in my event on Friday You will always find the busiest and most happening crowd on a Friday Nite in my event

Registration fees (payable in cash only) at the regn table@venue

LADIES: SS$10/- per pax for a glass of wine(Red/White) or soft drink

GENTLEMEN: S$15/- per pax for a glass of wine(Red/White) or soft drink

Ladies safety is my top priority.

Hence, ladies, please feel free to contact me if anyone breaks this rule

======

Venue:  MITZO RESTAURANT & BAR,

Level 4 Grand Park Orchard,
270 Orchard Road Singapore[masked]
T [masked]

The best seats in the house are arguably those at the Cocktail Atelier. With a 3 metre long jellyfish tank as backdrop, and illumination from the glittering bar top, the space is truly a vision to behold. This coveted space seats up to 6 and allows one to watch our cocktail craftsmen in action as they whip up delectable concoctions.

The 82-seat restaurant at the Grand Park Orchard hotel, which opened in Dec 2014, offers contemporary Cantonese restaurant as well as artisan cocktails. The restaurant is headed by chef Nicky Ng, former executive chef of modern Chinese restaurant Hakkasan in New York, while behind the bar is Jacek Piasecki, who runs Sling In, a top bar in Helsinki.

Chill out, wind down, or warm up to a night out.

Register for event at the registration counter of the venue and receive a drink coupon (redeemable at the bar counter) and a name tag. Please wear the name tag always during the event with a name (real or not). The Bar and/or Organiser reserve the right to ask any person, not having a name tag to leave without assigning any reasons thereof

Dress code:
Smart casual attire . No flip-flops or slippers allowed

I will be there to meet and greet personally everyone of you

Francis

Founder and Main Organiser

https://www.facebook.com/francis.organiser

Please like my face book page with more than 5,600 likes 
https://www.facebook.com/singapore.friendsclub

PS: Please read updated FAQ below before coming to my event to have answers to your doubts/worries and to avoid any misunderstanding

FAQ (Frequently Asked Questions)

Question: Hello! I would like to go to this event. But I am very new to the group. Is it okay to go this event by myself? Thanks!

Yes, most of the newbies come by themselves. But after attending my event; they go back with a big circle of new friends.

If you are attending the event for the first time, it is only natural you get a bit nervous. Do not worry, meet me or Guest Host and inform that you want to be introduced .We will be very much pleased to help you.

How to identify me? I am an Indian with a name tag “FRANCIS ORGANISER"

Question: Hmm..i was there outside but too shy to go inside by myself. Prolly just go somewhere in the area. Next time hopefully. More guts

Hi, sorry to hear that you outside my meetup but too shy to come inside. Being newbie, I can understand your fear and anxiety. Few years back, I was also a shy newbie like you.

Next time, please go to registration counter at the venue and request staff to meet organiser. The staff will inform me. I will come, personally welcome you and introduce to others.

Question: We register when we come that night at Venue?

Yes, you have to register again at the venue.

Members who do not register at the event, arguing that they have already RSVPed in the Meetup website, will be asked to leave the venue

Question: This is my first time joining such event. How do I register again at the venue?

Hi , welcome to my event. When you reach the venue, you will see Registration Table, with a signage “Francis Meetup Event” on the table. Please tell the staff that you are coming for Francis Meetup Event. Pay in cash, registration fees and get a drink coupon and a blank name tag.

Question: Can I bring my friend who is not in the group?

Sure, you can bring your friend, who is not in the group. Please register for your friend also at the registration table

Question: we are very new to this group :) who do we look for when we get there?

You can always look for me (Francis Organiser) when you reach venue. C u in the event

Question:I'm newbie and do not know anybody. How to start a conversation?

My group members are very friendly. So don't be shy and say "hello" or address them by names in their name tags  You never know where the conversation might lead to! friendship or may be relationship.

Question:What is the best time to make more friends?

Please come between 7-8pm. During the period, members will go around, mingle, make new friends and form small groups based on work, hobby, interest, etc

Question:How to identify the venue of this Meetup?

Most of the time, we will have our own signage. Hence please look for signage with words “FRANCIS MEETUP EVENT” at Registration Counter and at the entrance of the venue

Question: hello! am new and haven't exactly tried such meetups so cld I ask how do we recognise each other?

It is very easy to recognize other members since all my members will have name tags. Most of my events are private events. Hence you can mingle with others freely

Question: Is it mandatory for everyone to wear nametag? Im not comfortable doing thar in a public event

If you are not comfortable to write your real name in name tag, you can have any other name or blank name tag. If you are not having name tag, other members will think that you are not from Meetup group and you may not able to mingle with others in the event

Question:My work will end late ... Can I get there by 8pm 

Yes, but my only worry is that if you come late, you may lose the golden opportunity to meet most of the interesting members.

Question:I will be bringing guests with me.. I hope it’s not too late to inform.

Sure, please bring your friends, colleagues and business associates who  want to go to a party that is really happening.

description:
After the winter we've had, a tropical getaway is sounding pretty good.  I've found a home in old Puerto Vallarta, poised on the hill overlooking the famous Playa Los Muertos (of Night of the Iguana fame).  

We can have the place for nine nights, Friday April 10 through Sunday Apriel 19... airport pick up, drop off is included, along with maid service, breakfast fixings and food staples.


The casa is traditional in design, with painted tile and stucco.  It features a private garden, large patio, pool and a balcony for optimal sunset viewing.  The home backs up to the jungle and is reached by funicular from street level.  It has four bedrooms and 3.5 baths.  The large master has an en suite bath, available for an extra $250.


The kitchen is great, and will be stocked with wine, water, breakfast fixings and other food staples.  We'll have the maid come in every other day or so.


This vacation is all about convenience and lazy, sunny days... It's going to be a pretty unstructured trip.  Though I'm thinking of primarily of the beach and pool (and blended margaritas, there are many activities available... snorkeling and eco tours of the jungle, spas and museums.  


The casa is 5 to 10 minutes walk from downtown so we can walk to the beach, to dinner, or to shop, though cabs are plentiful and affordable.

The price for the trip is $1250 for nine nights, ground only.  All activities are extra, though I'm happy to help making arrangements for snorkeling, spas, jungle tours, etc.

We need to book this quickly, or we risk losing out.  I do have a backup casa in mind with similar amenity and a few nice perks, but I hope we get this one!
name: Escape to Tropical Puerto Vallarta, 9 Nights for from $1250 to $1800

Grade: Easy to Moderate (lots of hard packed gravel sections) 

Distance: 25 or 50km return (from market two choices can jump on train or ride back) (looking at averaging 10 to 20 km/h)

What To Bring: ,Your self, some friends ,2 full Water bottles , Spare Tube (best to bring two as not very close to train stations) Patch kit ,tools pump  etc oh and a sense of Adventure also:)  also a snack in case.

Before Ride. please check pressure in tyres (should be inflated to within recommended pressure which can be found on side wall of tyre)  and check for wear on the tread
name: Cycle to Eltham market 25-50km

description:
SO BE SURE TO RSVP FOR THIS BY PHONE, SO HANNA WILL KNOW. This
Work of Byron Katie® Inquiry meeting is held each 2nd Tuesday
evening at The Gateway in West Los Angeles (new address is at the
NW corner of the Barrington & Gateway intersection,
kitty corner to the old location): 2511 S. Barrington Ave, Ste 100,
Rm III -- (2nd Fl by elevator or stairs) -- RSVP by the Monday night before each 2nd Tuesday
meeting; or by phone to The Gateway at[masked] or Hanna at
[masked] (or TEXT to Jeff Jones's cell,[masked]) no later
than Monday night. Drop ins are welcome but may be disappointed as
no meetings occur if there are no rsvps and event may cancel if no
RSVPs are confirmed by the Monday before each meeting. Eckhart
Tolle calls The Work of Byron Katie® "a
great blessing for our planet." Here's an opportunity to experience
the profoundly simple 4 question inquiry process that noted author
Wayne W. Dyer says "has been enormously helpful to me personally."
Find out for yourself at this exciting new Westside venue and once
monthly event. A great workshop for anyone drawn to
Self-Improvement, Personal Inquiry, Spirituality and
Transformation: An Introduction to 'The Work of Byron Katie®' ~
Hanna Levinson presents and facilitates in West Los Angeles
(every 2nd Tuesday) at 7:00pm @ The Gateway / a Portal for
Growth & Wellness, 2511 S. Barrington Ave, Suite 100, Rm III
(2nd floor by elevator/stairs). The Gateway is at the NW Corner of
Gateway Blvd. & Barrington Ave. (www.mapquest.com) Requested
Donation is $20 per person or $35 per couple. To confirm
attendance and reserve space(s), please contact Tony or Heidi at
The Gateway[masked] or call Hanna at[masked]-1778. For
questions about The Work, call Hanna directly or call Jeff Jones at
[masked] cell or[masked]-2923. This is not a training or a
belief system. It is more akin to engaging from your heart in an
active cognitive meditation. Events like this can be a combination
of discussion, presentation, and activity, with elements of all
three but mostly are one-on-one with each participant and other
participants observing and providing feedback at the end of each
investigation. Individual sessions can often be emotionally
difficult, highly humorous, heart wrenching, heart-warming,
motivational and inspiring. Hanna Levinson* an active facilitator
of The Work since 1998, will facilitate each meeting inviting you
to investigate your most stressful thoughts and limiting beliefs
(for those willing to write them down and take a look) with 4
Questions and a Turnaround or two. Inquiry via The Work of Byron
Katie offers remarkable, measurable and palpable shifts by
answering the 4 Questions from a place of personal integrity and
being present to the current experience (in Tolle speak: being in
the now of our lives). *Hanna Levinson, www.truthpoint.net
([masked])[masked], attended The first European
Certification Training Program for the Work of Byron Katie® in
1999 in Amsterdam and started the first Westside Work group in
Santa Monica, CA in 1998 shortly after experiencing The Work. The
Santa Monica group was ongong from 1998 through 2004 with Hanna as
its main facilitator and continued in Santa Monica with Jeff Jones
from 2004-2008. Jeff left Santa Monica in 2006 and expanded Inquiry
into Sierra Madre and the Pasadena area on the East side of LA to
Venice in the Marina del Rey area on the West side. Hanna
facilitates at least once a month and meets privately with
individuals and groups upon request. She employs this work in her
own life and thoroughly enjoys being of service via Inquiry and The
Work of Byron Katie® as often as the opportunity arises. For
information about greater Los Angeles events featuring The Work of
Byron Katie®, contact Jeff Jones at [masked] or
[masked] cell;[masked] home. For more on The Work of Byron
Katie® and to download worksheets, go to www.thework.com
name: The Work in West L.A.@The Gateway, with Hanna

description:
One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of one of the most misunderstood and challenging ideas in many eastern philosophies; non-attachment. Many philosophical and spiritual traditions identify the lack of detachment with the continuous worries and restlessness produced by desire and personal ambitions. This event will provide the opportunity for a thoughtful and engaging discussion on how non-attachment can be put into practice in our modern lives. This will be event #22 for our group in Vancouver. 


Psychology Dinners Event Information

Click here to sign up for the Self-confidence event taking place on Sunday March 15.


Please remember to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to the event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event


As per usual, our discussion facilitators will be provided with thought-provoking questions to fuel the discussions (available soon). Our members take turns facilitating these discussions. As the coordinator for all of our groups around the world, I'm the one who coordinates the facilitators for events prior to the event taking place (with one facilitator for every table of 6 people). I also facilitate events which take place in Vancouver.


If you want to attend this event then RSVP 'Yes' via this web page and follow the instructions to pay the small fee online. Cash payment is not accepted at the door. Click here to read why this is the case.


Why is there a small fee? Click here to read the reasons why there is a small fee to attend our events.



For more information on Philosophy Dinners please visit ourFAQs page and our home page:

philosophydinners.org


Sincerely, 
Glen Brauer 
Founder, Facilitator and Event Coordinator 
http://philosophydinners.org/ 
https://www.facebook.com/groups/philosophydinners
name: Non-attachment (appetizers & discussion)

description:
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 3.6 miles round trip
Elevation gain: 590 feet
Difficulty: Easy

Tamanawas Falls forms a broad curtain where Cold Spring Creek thunders over a 150’ lava cliff near the eastern base of Mount Hood. This hike along scenic Cold Spring Creek has been a traditional trek for families.

The hike begins at the Sherwood Trailhead. From the large parking area, walk through the woods toward the roaring East Fork of the Hood River to find the trail, where it crosses the raging stream on a massive, new log bridge (installed in 2007 after floods removed the former bridge). Turn right after crossing the bridge, and follow the East Fork Trail (no. 650) north as it gradually climbs high above the river and highway. At the half-mile mark, pass a viewpoint and round the corner into Cold Spring Creek canyon. The trail drops gently, and soon reaches the East Fork-Tamanawas Falls Trail Junction, where you head straight (left) toward a bridge over Cold Spring Creek. The continuation of the East Fork Trail heads north (right), and is an alternate route to the falls from the Polallie Trailhead.

After crossing the creek, the trail ambles upstream, always within sight of the rushing stream, which tumbles over a series of tiny waterfalls. At 1.5 miles beginning climbing above the creek on a section of new trail. Pass the signed Tamanawas Falls-Tamanawas Falls Tie Trail Junction on the right, and then pass a second unsigned junction for the same trail (#650B). Continue on to Tamanawas Falls, crossing the upper reach of the large rock fall for a quarter mile. Beyond the rock fall, the trail enters forest, and soon arrives at a fine view upstream to Tamanawas Falls, at the 2 mile mark. From here, you can simply enjoy the falls from the trail, or follow one of the use paths for a closer look. Sure-footed hikers can climb the talus to the right of the falls to reach the amphitheater behind the falls.
name: Tamanawas Falls Hike

Tickets are advance purchase  

Ticket Link:  http://uncorkeddenver-foppiano-warwick.eventbrite.com

What: Foppiano Portfolio Wine Tasting with Highly rated wines (90+) from the esteemed Northern California winemaker Louis Foppiano on the beautfiul patio at the Warwick (yeah...the place with the Playboy Twist!)  We will be sampling wines from Louis Foppiano's Sonoma Vineyard

We will be on the patio weather permitting.  If there is cold, snow rain/wind we will be INSIDE Randolph's

Where: Warwick Hotel in a private patito wine and food pairing at Randolphs in the place famous for the Playboy Club. 1776 Grant Street Denver, CO 80203 www.warwickdenver.com FREE VALET PARKING

Crowd: Young/Mid Professionals  (Most of our crowd is 30's to 50's but everyone is welcome to our winemaker events.

When: Tuesday April 7, 2015  Please be prompt as we will be serving each wine and appetizer paired

Dress: Dressy Casual/Dress to Impress

Cost: $ 29.99 includes tax and tip (Wine Party Only)   Ticket Link:  http://uncorkeddenver-foppiano-warwick.eventbrite.com

Dress: Business/Dressy Casual to Business/Dress to Impress

Wines and Food Pairing  TBA

Accolades/ratings of wines  http://www.foppiano.com/in-the-news

Founded in 1896 by Giovanni Foppiano, Foppiano Vineyards is one of Sonoma County's oldest continually-operated, family-owned wineries. Our family has supplied northern California with wine for over a century, surviving Prohibition in the 1920s by selling home winemaking kits.

Louis Foppiano is 4th generation and grew up in the winemaking business.  Over the years, Louis has worked in just about every position at the winery: driving the tractor in the vineyards; working the bottling line, crush pad and fermenting tanks; and, later after graduating from college, representing the winery around the world through sales and marketing.

Like the three generations before him, Louis Foppiano has set the simple goal of creating honest, consistent, high quality wines, which are meant to be enjoyed at the table with family and friends. Under his direction, Foppiano Vineyards has enjoyed great success, increased prosperity, and critical acclaim.

ASSUMPTION OF RISK - WAIVER AGREEMENT http://www.meetup.com/denverwine/pages/ASSUMPTION_OF_RISK_-_WAIVER_AGREEMENT

This group is for you soulful, positive energy, professional, light souls who are ready to receive miracles, to transform, change or enhance your life, to manifest your highest potential, to gain clarity and Self- empowerment. 

This group is for Intelligent and creative people who seem to have “everything” but still have a sense that they are missing “something”?

You may be feeling a little “stuck” or “confused” and could use some deep inner guidance. Or you may simply benefit from the right spark of insight to move you forward. In either case, Elizabeth can see the “energy” and help you surface the issue that is blocking your growth.

If you are suffering from a “lost of innocence,” she can help you gain back your power, integrity and self respect. And for those who lost their loved ones, whether in childhood or in adulthood, she can help you reconnect and heal old wounds. In both cases, you will put a closure to the past, which will bring you peace in the present moment.

ARE YOU READY TO INVEST IN YOUR LIFE? WOULD YOU LIKE TO START FRESH! TO GIVE YOURSELF A LIFE SAVING GIFT OF ENLIGHTENMENT, MORE JOY, HAPPINESS AND ZEST INTO YOUR LIFE?

 If you are conscious and aware, seeking more spiritual growth, and ready to explore new horizons of inner being... then please, join our group!

Since this is a combined New Moon and High Holy Day, we ask for a suggested donation of $20.

description:
A not-to-be-missed evening of colourful Armenian music, featuring brilliant Armenian guest artists. The programme includes a new suite from Oscar-winning Canadian composer Mychael Danna’s score for Atom Egoyan’s film Ararat, and a collection of exquisite songs by composer Gomidas, arranged by Serouj Kradjian. 

We will be attending this concert in partnership with our sister group, the TSG Toronto Social Group.

Performers

• Peter Oundjian, conductor

• Isabel Bayrakdarian, soprano

• Sergey Khachatryan, violin

• Serouj Kradjian, piano 


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUiZomzTs-Q

Click on the video above to get an idea of a typical performance. 

Our Seats 

As usual, we have reserved seats in the balcony in section R8 & L8. Every seat at the Roy Thompson Hall is a good seat. We are especially close to the orchestra stage sitting above it. 

Price

Our special group discounted ticket price is $40.50 ea. All taxes and ticket/box office fees are included. 

Payment

Payment is required when you RSVP. Please note that payment is required to reserve a ticket for you. Payment can be made with all major credit cards or Paypal. A Paypal account is not required. If you wish to use an alternate payment method, I can also accept cash or email money transfer. Please contact me for further details. 

Ticket Pickup & Meeting Point 

I will be standing next to the box office window from 7:30 to 7:55 PM, wearing a large yellow name tag with my name on it. At 7:55 PM, I will go inside and get seated. If you arrive after 7:55 PM, please identify yourself to the staff at the customer service desk and they will give you your ticket.
name: Toronto Symphony Orchestra's Ararat: Music Of Armenia with Isabel Bayrakdarian

description:
Bushcraft is a term often used to describe skills that allow us to live comfortably outdoors, using natural resources in a responsible and sustainable manner. Learning and practicing Bushcraft is an empowering experience especially for those of us that spend the majority of our times indoors.

So what better way to learn more about living outdoors than to get out into the countryside and to explore it.

This session is free of charge and will involve a walk across some of Sussex's beautiful countryside, along a part of the South Downs Way and then off into some of the lesser known paths. We will meet at Ditchling Beacon car park. Please review their website for details of car park payment using the new RingGo system (National Trust).  Sadly the no. 79 bus does not start running until 10:00 on a Sunday, but you can catch it back to Brighton up to 16:42 (according to their website : http://www.buses.co.uk/travel/service.aspx?serviceid=1201).

We will cover some basic navigation (with compass and natural navigation), plant and tree identification, natural history, and we can all share our knowledge and experience of the outdoors.

The walk will be approximately 13 Km (8 miles) over varied terrain. We will be looking to cover this in 4-5 hours, allowing time to stop and explore what we find along the way. We will start the walk at 09:00 promptly so please ensure that you arrive by 08:45 at the latest.

Please bring your own lunch and snacks and also dress for the weather. We will walking at a gentle pace, but you will need to wear walking boots/shoes and bring a suitable ruck sack with waterproof clothing, water and snacks.

The day is open to anyone over 12 years old, but those under 18 years old must be accompanied by an adult (ratio of 2 children to 1 adult).

For more info about us, check out <a>www.at-one-with-nature.co.uk</a>

For more about this, please see our previous walk. This will follow the same route and cover similar topics : http://meetu.ps/2qlqfW
name: Walk and Learn - outdoor appreciation (no charge)

description:
Meet amazing like minded people & Learn all the tools you need for a lifelong Meditation Practice with the Legendary Modern day Monks/teachers of The Bright Path!

Friday March 20th - 7 - 10pm

Sat March 21st - 10am  -5pm

Sun March 22nd - 10am -4.pm

Join us for this First Sphere Weekend in Salt Lake City & to learn how to meditate! This simple yet profound Meditation will give you all the skills you need for an effective, simple meditation practice for life. No beliefs or special postures required. All are welcome!  You can then repeat this course anywhere in the world for free. Life time support from fully qualified teachers of  the Bright Path too! 6 Weekly group meetings and follow up advisable. Are you ready?

Why can't I learn the Bright Path Meditation online or from a book? See this short video on why its best to learn face to face, below.

http://youtu.be/T7vEBa6eHCo

Absolute Inner Peace already exists. It is not anywhere else but within the core of your being. It is the silent place that never comes and never goes; it is a place that you can experience simply by detaching your attention from the loud and changeable.

Experience is everything, there are some things you need to experience personally to get the full benefits. Meditation, because some questions can't be answered by Google!.


That place is the source of all peace, joy and love. And it is your choice whether to experience it or not, moment by moment. You don’t need to beg for peace from the outside, but to fully recognize that you have it already within yourself. Ultimately you will realize that you are not having or feeling peace; but you are Peace itself.

Everyone deserves to live a life of unbounded peace,without exception. True Inner Peace doesn’t belong to someone that’s more fortunate or special; it belongs to anyone who wants more of it in their lives, and is willing  explore that.

What you are searching for is already there. It has been waiting for you to stop running away from it and recognize that it's Presence has always been within you.

Are you ready to experience that peace? Then simply RSVP Now!

The cost of this weekend (including the 6 week follow up teaching/coaching  with Bright Path teachers/ Ishaya Monks is $400. 

($50 deposit secures your place.) But hurry places are limited!
name: Learn how to Meditation in this fun Meditation Weekend Course!

description:
Meeting at McDonalds located in Westmead (also a servo) at 8:30am and heading to Wilberforce Shell service station (for those with small tanks its rougly 185km from Westmead McDonalds to the petrol station at the end of Putty rd. You may need a top up at the Shell servo in Wilberforce, or alternatively make sure you have enough petrol to get you from McDonalds Westmead to the Shell servo in Wilberforce, which is 33kms, and you can fill up there). We will then head up Putty Road to the Grey Gum Café for a coffee and a quick bite (about 80km in) then the ride rest of Putty Road stopping in Bulga for petrol. From Bulga we then head back the way we came and head to Broke and onto paynes crossing road/great N road/George downs road where we will have another quick stop at Jerrys café to stretch the legs. then we head onto peats ridge road to Calga where you can choose to either take the m1 or the old pac home (depending on fatigue and how well we made time) map shows the last stop point at pie in the sky on old pac for those wanting to go that way.

this is a long day out on the road but its a day not to be missed such great roads! for everyone's enjoyment can we try to make petrol stops as fast as possible so that the café stops can be longer, it makes it more enjoyable!

as always please get to to the meetup point atleast 10 minutes before we leave (especially for this one its a long day and we wont want to be wasting any good riding time)

description:
Join us for a fun day of prepping donated fur coats for The Animal Rights Coalition's Cuddle Coats program. No previous Cuddle Coats experience is needed.

We will be hosting a Cuddle Coats prep session at the Fuller Park Building from 1-4 pm, and then we will head over to Minnesota's only vegan store, Ethique Nouveau for a vegan pizza party. The Animal Rights Coalition will be providing vegan pizzas from Galactic Pizza, but it would be awesome if you brought your own plates, silverware, and beverage - cuz' The Earth and all. :)

We are asking that if you will be attending the pizza party, you attend the full three hour prep session. We have piles and piles of furs to prep so we could use all of the help we can get. Plus, it's baby season for wildlife rehabs and lots of rehabs are waiting for furs to be shipped out to them. 

Prepping furs can be a messy job, so wear clothes that you don't mind getting dusty and feel free to bring a lint roller. Don't worry, you'll have time to wash up before the eating begins.

We hope to see you there! Learn more about Cuddle Coats at http://cuddlecoats.com/.
name: Cuddle Coats Prep Session And Vegan Pizza Party

description:
Hello, 

We are spending Easter Monday, on a very special foodie safari. We are having the "Radio Cairo" experience, which brings together the tasty flavours of the world's most exotic and exciting places. 

The Where in the World are we Eating series, is taking us to Mozambique, Sri Lanka, Cuba, New Orleans, India and South Africa.


The Restaurant: Radio Cairo

http://radiocairo.com.au/my-history.html


The Food

http://radiocairo.com.au/pdf/radiocairo-menu-prix-fixe.pdf

http://radiocairo.com.au/my-food.html

Radio Cairo have a really great value banquet, which has a big variety of international dishes.

We are going to have a 10 course Banquet, with sides for only $45 per person (the price includes the 10% public holiday surcharge). Drinks are to be paid separately by the individuals.


Entrees

- SNACK AFRO FRIES - Crispy spice dusted jacket potatoes & “allioli” mayonnaise

- PAPPADUMS - Indian lentil crisps

- KINGSTON’S ROAST EGGPLANT & YOGHURT DIP Pomegranate drizzle & pappadum shards

- LIMPOPO CROCODILE WINGS - Tender tangy char-grilled chicken wings with African peach dipping sauce. “have you ever tried to pluck a crocodile!”

- SOUTH AFRICAN LAMB SOSATIES

Succulent fillets of lamb marinated in spicy apricot, char-grilled South African style on a skewer-served with sour cream, cheese & chilli

- CAJUN POPCORN - New Orleans style seasoned shrimp & spicy apricot sauce


Mains

- BUZZARD & SWEET POTATO CURRY

This delicious recipe originated in a remote bush café stylishly called Café de Paris; en route to a jungle safari
in an area where one is never quite sure what meat is used chicken or buzzard. That night we weren’t eating chicken-tonight you are!

- CUBAN JUJU SIRLOIN SLIPPERS

Angus grass-fed sirloin steak slippers BBQ’d with exotic Juju-Cubano spice rub-served with sour cream & fresh cut chilli

- MOZAMBIQUAN TIGER PRAWNS PIRI PIRI

The perfect marriage of tiger prawns & spicy Portuguese flavours, found anywhere on the coast near Lourenco Marques in Mozambique Served with a squeeze of lemon & roast garlic mayonnaise

- CAJUN ‘BLACKENED’ SNAPPER FILLETS

Snapper fillets crusted in the pan with Cajun spices, succotash-slaw & Louisiana hot sauce


Sides

- SRI LANKAN KAHA RICE - Traditional style tempered rice

- CUCUMBER & YOGHURT + NIGELLA SEED ‘RAITA’ SALAD SOUTH INDIAN SWEET MANGO CHUTNEY


RSVP 

Please only RSVP if you have a genuine interest in coming along.


Cheers

Amy

_________________________________________________

The Original Concept Behind the 2015 Where in the World Are We Eating Series:


Hello, 

The Where in The World are we Eating Series are my favourite Foodie Adventurer's events. :)


'Bean' Around The World?

The inspiration for the postcard (courtesy of my trip to Queenstown, NZ)

For those who've been abroad, have the travel bug or travel wannabee's.... here's a series of Foodie Adventurers which will take you around the culinary world. These unique foodie events are inspired by your travel stories, and hopefully many more adventures to come...


Foodie Adventure's... Let the Journey Begin!

I'm running a series of Foodie Adventures called 'Where in the World are we eating??.... It's The Foodie Traveller's Adventure Guide to exploring the world just a hop, skip and a jump away. No flights just involved... maybe a bus or short train trip? Too easy right. ;)


The Travel Plan  

We travel around the culinary world via food, trying different cuisines across Sydney. 

Just like countries, I've picked a series of restaurants which help represent the culture, cuisine and atmosphere. It's cheaper than a round the world trip for sure! ;) 

Finally, you get to tick if off your travel list! Been there, done that.... Yumo! and where are we going next??


There are 7 continents in the World. There are 196 countries in the World.... where are we eating??? 

Where Are We Eating in 2015?

How many restaurants have i picked 2015??? Hmmm... that is the mystery question. I have some old sentimental favourites, that i would like to revisit. 

Let's go back to Spain for some Tapas, discover the nations of Africa, a visit to Santorini might be nice too (or I'll take any Greek Island;)), my favourite is French... Ooh La La.... 

And many new countries yet to conquer, including Persia, Greece and Morocco. The world is our oyster, only limited by the limitations of your tastebuds. 

Basically, we could visit any country, as long as it's public transport friendly.  


Designer Banquets

Banquets are the best way to go, as you get to try so many different foods. I often design my own banquets based on Restaurant Favourites, My Favourites and Crowd Favourites.

Best to budget around $40 to $50 for dinner.


2014 Happy Holiday Travel Memories

In 2014, we travelled the globe several times. I hosted more than 30 Where in The World Are We Eating foodie events. 

We have certainly grown in size. The Foodie Adventurer's meetup is a multi-cultural group of foodies, who love food! :)

2014 Foodie Photo Galleries - Our Travel Happy Snaps 

Where in the World is The Exotic Spice Room - Saffron, Paprika & Bay Leaves

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=25759434


Where in the World are we having the Baccomatto Osteria Italian experience?

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=25732414


Where in the World are we Eating? Tetsuya inspired Confit of Salmon dish :)

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=24699302


Where in the World are Eating? The Indo Chine Culinary Journey to Viet Town :)

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=24256142


RSVP 

This is a NOTICE BOARD only. I'm going to start posting up some events starting in January 2015, with some interesting menus and locations.... look out for the events soon. In the meantime, here's some food for thought. :)


Cheers,

Amy
name: Where in the World will the foodie trail lead to Mozambique, Sri Lanka & Africa?

description:
The strength of the Ancestors system lies in the conceptual understanding of body kinetics and Internal energy flow.

Whether you are fit or not, woman or man, this is a slow motion practise focused on understanding your body structure and "listening" to the person you are in contact with.

This unique interpretation of the Shaolin Ancestors system by Siukee Wan can be viewed as a modern translation of Traditional Chinese Martial Arts without any of its mythical and sometimes theatrical expressions and reveals the Yi (Essence) in Kung Fu which is so often cleverly concealed behind a Master’s hands. One of our aims is to reveal some of Kung Fu’s best kept secrets and present it in a way which makes it very applicable for martial arts training in the 21st Century.

For more information about Master Siu Kee or about Shaolin arts, visit:

http://www.shaolinancestors.com
name: EXTRA:Introduction to the art of SHAOLIN Tai Chi / Wing Chun with Master Siu Kee

description:
Are you looking for ways to document your goals and track them easily? Do you find it difficult to follow through the goals you set for yourself?

THERE ARE PROVEN SOLUTIONS TO MAKE YOU FOLLOW THROUGH YOUR GOALS, so set yourself for success now!

By attending this event, you will get the following:

• you will have precisely documented your goals using all best practices from the field experts

• you will have put in place a highly effective process to review your goals each month

• you will have the opportunity to partner with another person to hold yourself accountable for following through your goals

The cost for this event grants you a full copy of a "Life compass" tool, a compiled version of the best elements from all famous models: the Secret (Rhonda Byrne), the 7 habits of highly effective people (Stephen Covey), the Power of Full Engagement (Tony Schwartz), and Getting Things Done (Dave Allen).


Note: this is a re-run from the January sessions, here is some feedback from people who are just like you:

"Great ! Very useful and thorough tool, while being easy to follow. 10/10 Would come again."

"Great workshop with like minded people, extremely useful tools that will definitely help anyone achieve their goals if they are genuinely serious about reaching the gold."

"Useful meetup. There is nothing better than well polished excel sheet that arranges something vague by nature."

"Definitely worth the 2 hour journey from Reading!"

description:
!!!!! NEW DATE is 21. March - 23. March (Saturday to Monday). There is a chance that we will only go for one night, will decide closer to the day.

!!!!! PLEASE CHECK if those dates work for you, and alter your RSVP accordingly! Also, if many people would prefer to do this trip Friday morning to Sunday evening instead, we can do that too - please LET ME KNOW your preference there as well.

!!!!! If weather is not that great, we will still go, but likely stay in the hut two nights, and not camp one night. Weather will decide that closer to the day.

Three awesome days and two nights in the area around Wool Shed Creek Hut! We'll walk up to grassy plains and along the tops on day one, and spend the first night camping in a beautiful safe location. On day two, we walk along some pretty interesting rock formations, down to the river, to the other side, and to Wool Shed Creek Hut, where we spend the second night. On day three we will follow the river downhill back to the car park.

For this trip, you should at least have some overnight experience with your children, such as from the Pack Horse Hut or the Bealey Spur trip - but if you do, this is an awesome next step up!

The meeting location in Christchurch will be announced closer to the day; we'll drive together from there. It's about two hours driving from Christchurch.

If you want to join us for this trip, please RSVP by clicking the button at the top right as soon as possible!

venue.name: Tour de Falls - Dupont State Forest

description:
***Update 3/8***

Ok folks, I've pedaled and pushed my bike up DuPont State Forest for 3 hours straight, then rode down 3 miles in just 20 minutes! Best ride I've had still, and I would like to share that experience with everyone, especially the first timer! We will start each day with steady climb for the first 2-3 miles. If that's too hard for you, it might be time to go back to the car... Becasue those will be the easier option of climbing up DuPont.

I had only 6 months of riding experience when I did that trip, and the group was all Advanced level riders, so I had to keep up. After 30 minutes in I was pushing the biking on the rest of the climb... So I know the pain of new rider going up DuPont for the first time, and It's ok to push the bike and it's ok to go back at the 2-3 mile mark. Safety first!!

We will make this out-of-town trip accessible for Beginners and Intermediate level riders.

Drive/carpool on Saturday and do a 2-3 hours ride.  Stay in the area with your choice of camping, cabin or cheapo-motel. I vote for ribs and pizza for dinner! Sunday after breakfast we will do a longer ride for 3+ hours. With the option of having lunch near by and head back to Charlotte.

If you know the trails well, or if you point me the right direction, any information is greatly appreciated!

DuPont Ride, Nothing is written in stone below; just my idea so far. Let me know what you think!

Day 1 ride 6.5 miles of going up on Double track and coming down on Single track!!

Park at Lake Imaging Parking Lot

Start on Lake Imaging Road, 1.6 miles of Double Track and a steady climb 270 feet up.

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5673155/lake-imaging-road

adding Hilltop Trail of 0.9 miles of Single Track of a smooth downhill.

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5673381/hilltop

Vidoe: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UNDUKELwbh0

Turn Left on to Buck Forest Road, about 1.25 mile of double track and easy climb.

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5673826/buck-forest-road

Turn Left on to DuPont Ridgeline Loop, 0.25 miles, Towards Hooker's Creek Trail

Hooker's Creek Trail, 1 mile of downhill then climb of Single Track

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/1026734/hooker-creek

Turn Left onto Ridgeline Trail, 1.3 miles of Single Track of downhill http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/1025538/ridgeline

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uiQXw2aEYWw

Turn Right on to Lake Imaging Road and back to the parking lot.

6.5 miles total


Day 2 ride 11 miles of hard Double and Single Track, with “bail out” option at 3.35 miles in. 

 The hardest climb finishes at the 3.35 mile mark with 400 feet of straight climb. The 2nd hardest climb is coming up next and we will climb 514 feet more!!! That's why there is a “bail out” option.

After we grind our way to the top, we will get 4 miles of sweet downhill sections plus 1.5 miles of easy ride back to the parking lot. It shall be epic!

Park at High Fall Parking

Start on Buck Forest Road for 0.75 Miles (bit uphill, gravel double track)

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5673826/buck-forest-road

Turn Left on to Conservation Road for 2.6 miles (Double Track gravel fire road and hard climb, 400 feet up). http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5674499/conservation-road

Picking up Reasonover Creek Trail for 1.2 miles. (Singletrack with a small creek crossing). We will start with a ¼ miles of downhill fun, and after 0.9 mile of climb, which is the 2nd hardest climb at 388 feet straight up.

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/6373431/reasonover-creek-trail

Ride video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eOx961eGYUs&list=PLqZa9KWvXjiDgu1E4EfWvhUGCJQf_Ue6S&index=40

at the fork (1.2 mile in), Turn Right onto Turkey Knob Road (1.7 miles of Doubletrack of a steady climbing) http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5675058/turkey-knob-road

Will will continue onto Turkey Knob Trail (don't get confused with the Turkey Knob Road...) One of the best downhill runs DuPont has to offer!! 1.4 miles and 313 feet down on Single track!

http://www.mtbproject.com/trail/5675125/turkey-knob

Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SbxY2u3tRhQ

Turn Right onto Briery Fork (0.4 miles on Single track with a easy climb)

Turn Left onto Joanna Road for 2.7 miles of fun. (Double track with a bit of climb, and 340 feet of downhill run!

Turn Right back onto Conservation Road for 0.4 miles

Turn Left onto Buck Forest Road for 0.75 miles back to the parking lot!!


Pre-Trip ride at WWC. Check the list below and bounce ideas around!! I'm thinking 2 weekends before the weekend trip. We will do a 30 minutes Q'n A on what to bring and what's expected. Also we can check everyone's bike to be tip-top shape.

Equipment must have list: A capable mountain bike (is has to handle real mountain terrain), helmet, spare tube (even you ride tubeless), bike pump (1 per 4 riders), plenty of water, snack bar/energy bar, back back, wear layers (mountain is a bit colder, in can we have to stop for a tire change). Bike tools. First aid kit (1 per 4 riders).

Optional equipment: Gloves, eye protection, bike lock (stay over night or eating at a restaurant), bear propellant, Go-Pro, extra pair of socks (in case you step into the water!).

We all stay in one big group to ensure everyone's safety. Rule #1, no one will be left behind; we start as a group, finish as a group. Rule #2, we go as fast as the slowest rider.

We will stay in vocal communication range. (now I know why Dirt Diva's all got bike bells). The “train” will be mixed with different skilled riders so we can keep an eye on the “trail”. If anyone needs to stop or slow down for any reason, please yell “Stopping” and/or ring your bell. This will ensure we stay together as a group. We will have skilled riders mixed with leading and sweeping. The trails I picked are pretty straight forward; however, it's real mountain biking, and faster riders will have to wait for us slower riders to catch up.

If we split into two groups, same rule apply above, just with two different speed group. Remember folks, this trip is geared towards Beginners/Intermediate Level riders. IT'S OK TO PUSH YOUR BIKE UP THE TRAIL. However, We will only split the groups up if the trail section is a steep climb, or a straight downhill. Stay with your speed group and communicate. The two groups will be just minutes apart and we will all meet up every 5 minutes to regroup.

Let's have a awesome weekend trip and many more to come!

Please have your bike in tip-top shape for this trip! I look forward to ride in the mountains when the weather warms up soon!

Let me know if you have other great ideas or something I've overlooked!
name: Dupont Mountain Biking Weekend Trip for Beginners and Intermediate Levels

description:
Hello,

Easter is just around the corner... For those who love to travel, then this foodie adventure will bring you back to one of our sentimental favourites...

For those looking for some 'spice to life', then you will really enjoy the tasty flavours of Indonesian cuisine.


The Language of Indonesian Food

Indonesian food, has a language of it's own. Whilst most asian cuisines, can be quite common in their names, you will be introduced to new foodie terms including Nasi Goreng,  Rendang and Sambals. 


Check out the foodie photos from our first visit in Feb:

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=25940313


The Restaurant: Delima

Our trip to Delima (our version of Bali) in February, brought a lot of joy. I discovered some new favourite dishes along the way... 


It's hard to forget, melt in your mouth chicken satays and tender juicy rendang beef curry.  The food was delicious. One of the foodies described the experience as 'Lip Smacking Good'.


The Food: Indonesian Cuisine

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/menu.php?category=1

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/menu.php?category=7


I'm going to be designing my own banquet, based on restaurant favourites, my favourites and crowd favourites. 

The budget for this banquet is $40 per person. With drinks to be paid separately by the individuals. 

Note: As it is a shared banquet, you will need to be able to eat anything. 


RSVP

Please only RSVP if you have a genuine interest in coming along.


Cheers

Amy

________________________________________________

Our First Visit to Delima in February:


Hello,

The Where in the World are we Eating is taking us back to the heart of Asia, to a country we have never visited... 

Chinese New Year brings a great range of cheap and cheerful banquet menus... 


This time we are visiting Indonesia, via the culinary journey. We are going to have a 7 course Indonesian Banquet for only $35. 


The Restaurant: Delima Restaurant

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/index.php


The Food 

I'm not sure what's on the final banquet menu. But for only $35 for 7 courses, then i think it's worth a try.


Here is a link to their regular menu for some food for thought. 

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/menu.php?category=7

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/menu.php?category=1


I am also going to be ordering some yummy traditional Indonesian desserts to share.

http://www.delimarestaurant.com.au/menu.php?category=5


RSVP 

Please only RSVP if you have a genuine interest in coming along.


Cheers

Amy

_________________________________________________

The Original Concept Behind the 2015 Where in the World Are We Eating Series:


Hello, 

The Where in The World are we Eating Series are my favourite Foodie Adventurer's events. :)


'Bean' Around The World?

The inspiration for the postcard (courtesy of my trip to Queenstown, NZ)

For those who've been abroad, have the travel bug or travel wannabee's.... here's a series of Foodie Adventurers which will take you around the culinary world. These unique foodie events are inspired by your travel stories, and hopefully many more adventures to come...


Foodie Adventure's... Let the Journey Begin!

I'm running a series of Foodie Adventures called 'Where in the World are we eating??.... It's The Foodie Traveller's Adventure Guide to exploring the world just a hop, skip and a jump away. No flights just involved... maybe a bus or short train trip? Too easy right. ;)


The Travel Plan  

We travel around the culinary world via food, trying different cuisines across Sydney. 

Just like countries, I've picked a series of restaurants which help represent the culture, cuisine and atmosphere. It's cheaper than a round the world trip for sure! ;) 

Finally, you get to tick if off your travel list! Been there, done that.... Yumo! and where are we going next??


There are 7 continents in the World. There are 196 countries in the World.... where are we eating??? 

Where Are We Eating in 2015?

How many restaurants have i picked 2015??? Hmmm... that is the mystery question. I have some old sentimental favourites, that i would like to revisit. 

Let's go back to Spain for some Tapas, discover the nations of Africa, a visit to Santorini might be nice too (or I'll take any Greek Island;)), my favourite is French... Ooh La La.... 

And many new countries yet to conquer, including Persia, Greece and Morocco. The world is our oyster, only limited by the limitations of your tastebuds. 

Basically, we could visit any country, as long as it's public transport friendly.  


Designer Banquets

Banquets are the best way to go, as you get to try so many different foods. I often design my own banquets based on Restaurant Favourites, My Favourites and Crowd Favourites.

Best to budget around $40 to $50 for dinner.

2014 Happy Holiday Travel Memories

In 2014, we travelled the globe several times. I hosted more than 30 Where in The World Are We Eating foodie events. 

We have certainly grown in size. The Foodie Adventurer's meetup is a multi-cultural group of foodies, who love food! :)

2014 Foodie Photo Galleries - Our Travel Happy Snaps 

Where in the World is The Exotic Spice Room - Saffron, Paprika & Bay Leaves

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=25759434


Where in the World are we having the Baccomatto Osteria Italian experience?

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=25732414


Where in the World are we Eating? Tetsuya inspired Confit of Salmon dish :)

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=24699302


Where in the World are Eating? The Indo Chine Culinary Journey to Viet Town :)

http://www.meetup.com/The-Foodie-Adventurers/photos/all_photos/?photoAlbumId=24256142


RSVP 

This is a NOTICE BOARD only. I'm going to start posting up some events starting in January 2015, with some interesting menus and locations.... look out for the events soon. In the meantime, here's some food for thought. :)


Cheers

Amy
name: Where in the World will we be celebrating Easter Saturday in Bali? ;)

description:
Are you looking for ways to document your goals and track them easily? Do you find it difficult to follow through the goals you set for yourself?

THERE ARE PROVEN SOLUTIONS TO MAKE YOU FOLLOW THROUGH YOUR GOALS, so set yourself for success now!

By attending this event, you will get the following:

• you will have precisely documented your goals using all best practices from the field experts

• you will have put in place a highly effective process to review your goals each month

• you will have the opportunity to partner with another person to hold yourself accountable for following through your goals

The cost for this event grants you a full copy of a "Life compass" tool, a compiled version of the best elements from all famous models: the Secret (Rhonda Byrne), the 7 habits of highly effective people (Stephen Covey), the Power of Full Engagement (Tony Schwartz), and Getting Things Done (Dave Allen).

If you already have your Life Compass from a previous session with Greg, these monthly events are FREE OF CHARGE.


Note: this is a re-run from the January sessions, here is some feedback from people who are just like you:

"Great ! Very useful and thorough tool, while being easy to follow. 10/10 Would come again."

"Great workshop with like minded people, extremely useful tools that will definitely help anyone achieve their goals if they are genuinely serious about reaching the gold."

"Useful meetup. There is nothing better than well polished excel sheet that arranges something vague by nature."

"Really great meet up, I've never written goals down before and just having done it makes me feel motivated. I really feel like I've got some direction this ear."

"Definitely worth the 2 hour journey from Reading!"
name: GOAL SETTING with the best in class "Life Compass" tool

description:
The hike will end later in the evening before sundown for Sunset colors. Bring a headlamp as a precaution.

Start point: Catherine Creek Trailhead
End point: Coyote Wall Viewpoint
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 8.2 miles
Elevation gain: 1750 feet
Difficulty: Moderate

This hike links the Catherine Creek area with the Coyote Wall area. There are great views of the Columbia River, the east end of the Columbia River Gorge, Mount Hood, and a lot of wildflowers.

From the Catherine Creek Trailhead, there are two closed roads that go up from the parking area. For this hike, avoid Road 15, that goes left (northwest). Instead, follow Road 20 that goes right (northeast). The road soon drops down to Catherine Creek as it bubbles through a small oak forest.

About a quarter mile from the trailhead, near the creek, there's a road junction. The most-used path is now Road 21 which crosses Catherine Creek. There is a footbridge for hikers. Just before this, a road goes faintly left. Follow this faint road, which is the continuation of Road 20. Don't cross the creek.

From here, the road goes along the west side of Catherine Creek, a ways above the creek. This road is passable by 4 wheel vehicles, so it makes an easy hiking trail.

By mile 1.5 from the trailhead, when you reach another junction, you've gained 1000 feet of elevation. From here Road 20 goes left (west) out of the Catherine Creek drainage, over towards Coyote Wall and a fainter road continues north.

The trail over to Coyote Wall uses an old 4 wheel drive road grade, which makes it an easy hiking trail, gradually sloped and wide. There are a lot of bicycles that use this. Someone cuts the branches and trees that fall across the road. This is not a solitude hike, but it's far enough from trailheads there aren't too many people. Keep a watch for bicycles that can sneak up behind you and startle you. This trail ends at the Coyote Wall Trail at mile 4.1 from the Catherine Creek Trailhead. Go west to get the splendid views from the basalt rim at the Coyote Wall Viewpoint. Return the way you came or try one of the variations listed below.

At mile 1.7 is the high point of this hike at 1300 feet elevation. At mile 2.1 the trail crosses a stream. At mile 3.2 the trail crosses another stream. You could use these for drinking water, but in the late spring and summer they probably dry up. Between the two streams are several grassy ridges that go up and down from the trail. You can find many flat places you could pitch a tent at. It can get pretty windy here, so you might try to find the most protected place you can find.

Past the second stream, the trail drops 400 feet down to Coyote Wall. There are several private residences above you. We will NOT be hiking the top of Coyote Wall, That is another long Hike Altogether.
name: Catherine Creek to Coyote Wall Hike - AFTERNOON HIKE

description:
We are excited for our first MeetUp Polynesians and Friends!!!

One of the many past times we as Polynesians love to do is spend the day at the beach with our family and friends, having fun, being merry and of course can't forget the food!

Join us on a Sunday at the beach. You can swim, eat, talk, lie in the sun or play a game of Beach Volleyball with Christie an Olympian. If you have never played don't worry as it will be intimate enough that she can teach you the basics. For the Pro's out there....We love competition! 

We are all about family so bring your family along too. If you are single bring friends along just let us know how many guests so we can cater for everyone. If you are Solo great as we love confident people with groups of Polynesians!

Our goal is to make our MeetUp group like a Family. So we really just want to get to know our new family members first. It will be a very relaxed and informal way to meet and share ideas to support the Polynesian people and culture.
name: Eat and socialise at the beach and join in Beach volleyball with an Olympian

group.name: Sydney Polynesian's in Sport and Business Meetup

description:
Let's mingle for dinner at Morgans Teppanyaki Room (Morgans Seafood Restaurant) at Scarborough. Who doesn't love the food, fun and entertainment of a Teppanyaki bar. This will be a set menu at a cost of $63.50 per person (to be paid when you RSVP) which includes:

The restaurant does two sittings and we are booked into the 8.15pm time slot. We will mingle for a drink on the terrace from 7.15pm. Numbers are limited so get your RSVP in to avoid disappointment.

Drinks are to be purchased separately on the night. The booking has been made under the name 'Mingles'.

To avoid disappointment of missing out on any of the awesome food, please ensure you arrive by 8.00pm. Sorry, no changes can be made to the menu.

Morgans Teppanyaki Room

Nothing stirs the appetite like the aroma of exotic Asian spices, delicious seafood & prime cuts sizzling on the barbecue.

Master Teppanyaki chef Kim Eldridge & his team make dining in Teppanyaki both a memorable and a unique experience. They prepare a selection of menus including an A La Carte menu and a range of delicious multi-course banquets (up to 8 courses) for a set price.
name: Mingles Dinner @ Morgans Teppanyaki Room, Scarborough

description:
於復活節為您的生命加油！
Cheer Up your life in this Easter!

處身於競爭激烈的社會中，我們總是想超越別人。不停地忙碌，為的只是追求及達到一個又一個的目標。無論是金錢上，或是物質上，人都是無止境地渴望著。我們總是想比別人強，比別人更有成就。

We live in a competitive society, a rat race, we want to get ahead, we are constantly busy, pursuing our next goal, whether it be material possessions, comfort, a coveted position or even a life of ease with no worries. We desire to live stronger than others.

當我們停一停，諗一諗，究竟這一切的是為了什麼？當地我們停下來，才發現我們是這樣的孤獨，有甚麼可以於迷失中指引我們？

But If we pause and think, what are we running after, what is the purpose of it all, when we get tired, are we on our own, is there someone leading us.

這個營能幫助我們「越活越強」，找到人生目標，亦從屬靈角度使我們的人生變得更加豐盛！

This camp can help all of us to “LIVE STRONG” with a purpose, God promised us to give abundant life. Let's run, knowing that we may win this imperishable crown of life.

講者介紹 Speaker

劉盛嘉醫生(MBBS, BMedSci)，畢業於澳洲墨爾本大學。她是一名麻醉科專科醫生，同時亦熱衷於預防性保健的研究。

Dr. Jane Low, a Medical Doctor with an MBBS, BMedSci from the University of Melbourne, Australia. She specialises in Anesthesiology and also has a passion for preventive health.

她曾在澳洲、所羅門群島、台灣和泰國等不同國家為社區服務。劉醫生是國際演講家，熱衷於幫助年輕人做出積極的改變，為他們改善生活。

She has served the community in various countries including Australia, Solomon Islands, Taiwan and Thailand. Jane is an international speaker who is passionate about helping people make positive changes to dramatically improve their lives.

本營將以廣東話進行，同時會有小組討論、遊戲等不同活動，充滿歡樂！

This camp will be conducted in Cantonese, and also be time for discussions, games and lots of fun!!!

希望於這個復活節讓我們擁有更加豐盛的人生！這個營讓我們可以增進友誼，彼此了解及互相認識，並一起鼓勵大家尋找我們的人生目標。

We hope that this Easter holiday will empower us all to make choices that will positively impact our lives and those around us even better, we trust that we would develop friendships in this camp that will encourage each one to grow towards our goals.

description:
For information on trip price, itinerary, pickup locations and all other details, please click here. Please note that you MUST book your seat and pay for it through the ShortTrips.ca website.

Please join us on this terrific once a year opportunity for an extra long 5-hour spring time cruise aboard the MS Chi Cheemaun on Georgian Bay along the coast of the spectacular Bruce Peninsula.

As many of you know, the Chi-Cheemaun ferry normally transports passengers every day in the summer months between Tobermory and Manitoulin Island. It's winter home however is Owen Sound! Today we will be boarding the ferry on its very first sailing of the year as it moves from Owen Sound to Tobermory. Our bus will drop us off at the dock in Owen Sound and pick us up at the end of the cruise in Tobermory.

A lovely hot & cold lunch buffet is included with the tour price. The cash bar will be open for refreshments. Music will be playing throughout the boat. What better way to enjoy the spring breezes than from the deck of a boat on Georgian Bay while sipping your favourite brew!

What's Included?

• Round trip transportation from the Toronto area on deluxe highway motor coach.

• One way 5-hour cruise ticket aboard the MS Chi-Cheemaun included.

• Hot & Cold buffet on board the boat included. Cash bar is available for soft drinks and alcoholic beverages.

• Complimentary water and snacks on the bus included. 

• All tips included. HST extra.

I hope you will join us on this fun day out and I hope to see you on the trip! 

- Sash

This trip is being arranged by:

Marville Travel Ltd. 
(905)[masked] 
TICO #[masked]

For information on trip price, itinerary, pickup locations and all other details, please click here. Please note that you MUST book your seat and pay for it through the ShortTrips.ca website.
name: Bruce Peninsula & Georgian Bay 5-Hour Spring Time Cruise

description:
The hike will end later in the evening before sundown for Sunset colors. Bring a headlamp as a precaution.



Start point: Catherine Creek Trailhead
End point: Coyote Wall Viewpoint
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 8.2 miles
Elevation gain: 1750 feet
Difficulty: Moderate

This hike links the Catherine Creek area with the Coyote Wall area. There are great views of the Columbia River, the east end of the Columbia River Gorge, Mount Hood, and a lot of wildflowers.

From the Catherine Creek Trailhead, there are two closed roads that go up from the parking area. For this hike, avoid Road 15, that goes left (northwest). Instead, follow Road 20 that goes right (northeast). The road soon drops down to Catherine Creek as it bubbles through a small oak forest.

About a quarter mile from the trailhead, near the creek, there's a road junction. The most-used path is now Road 21 which crosses Catherine Creek. There is a footbridge for hikers. Just before this, a road goes faintly left. Follow this faint road, which is the continuation of Road 20. Don't cross the creek.

From here, the road goes along the west side of Catherine Creek, a ways above the creek. This road is passable by 4 wheel vehicles, so it makes an easy hiking trail.

By mile 1.5 from the trailhead, when you reach another junction, you've gained 1000 feet of elevation. From here Road 20 goes left (west) out of the Catherine Creek drainage, over towards Coyote Wall and a fainter road continues north.

The trail over to Coyote Wall uses an old 4 wheel drive road grade, which makes it an easy hiking trail, gradually sloped and wide. There are a lot of bicycles that use this. Someone cuts the branches and trees that fall across the road. This is not a solitude hike, but it's far enough from trailheads there aren't too many people. Keep a watch for bicycles that can sneak up behind you and startle you. This trail ends at the Coyote Wall Trail at mile 4.1 from the Catherine Creek Trailhead. Go west to get the splendid views from the basalt rim at the Coyote Wall Viewpoint. Return the way you came or try one of the variations listed below.

At mile 1.7 is the high point of this hike at 1300 feet elevation. At mile 2.1 the trail crosses a stream. At mile 3.2 the trail crosses another stream. You could use these for drinking water, but in the late spring and summer they probably dry up. Between the two streams are several grassy ridges that go up and down from the trail. You can find many flat places you could pitch a tent at. It can get pretty windy here, so you might try to find the most protected place you can find.

Past the second stream, the trail drops 400 feet down to Coyote Wall. There are several private residences above you. We will NOT be hiking the top of Coyote Wall, That is another long Hike Altogether.
name: Catherine Creek to Coyote Wall Hike - AFTERNOON HIKE

description:
South OC Loop - aka The Rollers

44 miles - 2,800 ft

Rollout time is 8:00 AM (daylight saving begins)

Irvine-Foothill Ranch-Mission Viejo-Laguna Hills-Irvine

Route

http://ridewithgps.com/routes/5249832

There is very little flat on this route so you can expect to either be going up or down.  Most of the route is rolling and there are two hilly sections.

Depending on the group size, I am expecting to stop for water or bathroom breaks two times andwill regroup as needed.

 

Helmets are mandatory on all BOBIE rides. Bring hydration, spare tube, nutrition and appropriate clothing to be comfortable during the entire ride. (The weather can and will change during the ride.) Be sure to have Sun Screen for HOT or SUNNY days. Please be sure to bring a "Road ID" or similar up to date IN CASE OF EMERGENCY INFO list with you on all BOBIE rides to allow others to help you if you are unable to help yourself.As with all BOBie rides this is a no drop ride. We will stop to regroup or rest, restroom and refuel as needed. Please read the description carefully to asses if your are well suited for this ride. 

DISCLAIMER: By being a member of this group or signing up for OR attending any BOBIE RIDE, EVENT OR Function you hereby agree to assume all risks and liability related to or resulting from any and all group functions. You agree that neither you nor any third party will hold any of the group's leaders or representatives liable for any injury, loss, or damage to your own person or any members of your family, friends, acquaintances, children, pets, or property, arising directly or as a consequence from a group activity. You also agree that your membership of this group is based on an "at will" basis.
name: South OC Loop (The Rollers) - Level 4+

description:
Ok folks, Sunday weather very nice and in the 60's and up to 68 degrees at 5pm.

Let's go by the USNWC.ORG official trail status at 11am Sunday!!  

This will be a fun ride for all skill levels. Fast riders will go fast, and slow riders will go slow. Usually we break into 2 or 3 speed groups.

Lake Loop to warm up the legs and group photo! If you're running late, meet us at the Lake Loop entrance.

Beginners will do the Lake Loop once or twice more. Intermediate/Advanced riders will take the North Trail and keep on going. Intermediate levels will take the "Blue" Main Trail, and the option to any of the "Black" level sections. Advanced will take the Figure Eight Trail, Wedge, Carpet, Tower, Goat and as many as you wish! There are many exits and we should be done within 2 hours.

We will meetup at 12:00pm to get geared up, and we will roll out at 12:15pm. Capable mountain bike and helmet are required. Water, gloves, eye protection, spare tire/pump, and wear layers! Bike rental is available for $20 - $40. Parking is $5 or per year is $40.

description:
The Nature of Effective Prayer  is the second class in a four part series exploring the writings of Dr. Ernest Holmes in his now classic book, The Science of Mind.   The class is an active dialogue among spiritual seekers and will include some experiential practices including meditation, affirmation, prayer, chanting and visualization.

The aim of  the teaching of Science of Mind and Heart is to heal our lives of  all discord, fear, superstition, guilt and sense being unworthy of the abundant gifts of Life.  We offer a practical approach to life that incorporates the perspectives of both modern science and spiritual faith.   We teach that wholeness is real, and it can be found at the very center of who and what we are  -  right now. 

There is a tuition cost for this class of $15 per session or $100 if paid in full by Week 3.
name: The Nature of Effective Prayer

description:
One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of one of the most misunderstood and challenging ideas in many eastern philosophies; non-attachment. Many philosophical and spiritual traditions identify a lack of detachment with the continuous worries and restlessness produced by desire and personal ambitions. This event will provide the opportunity for a thoughtful, respectful and engaging discussion on how non-attachment can be put into practice in our modern lives. This will be event #22 for our group in Vancouver. 


Please remember to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to the event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event


Psychology Dinners Event (Sunday March 15)

Many of our Philosophy Dinners members are also members of the Psychology Dinners group in Vancouver. Click here to sign up for the Self-confidence event and click here to view the Food for Thought videos for this event.


As per usual, our discussion facilitators will be provided with thought-provoking questions to fuel the discussions (available soon). Our members take turns facilitating these discussions. As the coordinator for all of our groups around the world, I'm the one who coordinates the facilitators for events prior to the event taking place (with one facilitator for every table of 6 people). I also facilitate events which take place in Vancouver.


If you want to attend this event then RSVP 'Yes' via this web page and follow the instructions to pay the small fee online. Cash payment is not accepted at the door. Click here to read why this is the case.


Why is there a small fee? Click here to read the reasons why there is a small fee to attend our events.



For more information on Philosophy Dinners please visit ourFAQs page and our home page:

philosophydinners.org


Sincerely, 
Glen Brauer 
Founder, Facilitator and Event Coordinator 
http://philosophydinners.org/ 
https://www.facebook.com/groups/philosophydinners
name: Non-attachment (appetizers & discussion)
