description:
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 3.6 miles round trip
Elevation gain: 590 feet
Difficulty: Easy


Tamanawas Falls forms a broad curtain where Cold Spring Creek thunders over a 150’ lava cliff near the eastern base of Mount Hood. This hike along scenic Cold Spring Creek has been a traditional trek for families.

The hike begins at the Sherwood Trailhead. From the large parking area, walk through the woods toward the roaring East Fork of the Hood River to find the trail, where it crosses the raging stream on a massive, new log bridge (installed in 2007 after floods removed the former bridge). Turn right after crossing the bridge, and follow the East Fork Trail (no. 650) north as it gradually climbs high above the river and highway. At the half-mile mark, pass a viewpoint and round the corner into Cold Spring Creek canyon. The trail drops gently, and soon reaches the East Fork-Tamanawas Falls Trail Junction, where you head straight (left) toward a bridge over Cold Spring Creek. The continuation of the East Fork Trail heads north (right), and is an alternate route to the falls from the Polallie Trailhead.

After crossing the creek, the trail ambles upstream, always within sight of the rushing stream, which tumbles over a series of tiny waterfalls. At 1.5 miles beginning climbing above the creek on a section of new trail. Pass the signed Tamanawas Falls-Tamanawas Falls Tie Trail Junction on the right, and then pass a second unsigned junction for the same trail (#650B). Continue on to Tamanawas Falls, crossing the upper reach of the large rock fall for a quarter mile. Beyond the rock fall, the trail enters forest, and soon arrives at a fine view upstream to Tamanawas Falls, at the 2 mile mark. From here, you can simply enjoy the falls from the trail, or follow one of the use paths for a closer look. Sure-footed hikers can climb the talus to the right of the falls to reach the amphitheater behind the falls.
name: Tamanawas Falls Hike

description:
8:30h sabado Raquetas/Ski a Pico del Nevero desde Navafría (PNERP)

Se trata de alquilar unas Raquetas o Skies de Travesía. Y subir desde el parking de la Navafría hasta el pico del nevero.

Track aproximado propuesto:

http://es.wikiloc.com/wikiloc/view.do?id=4311109

Se trata de una oportunidad muy buena para iniciarse en el uso de raquetas / ski de travesía. Ya que la subida es sencilla y la bajada es por las pistas acondicionadas para la practica del ski fondo. Por lo que no existirá descenso fuera de pista.

El alquiler de las raquetas se podrá realizar en alguna tienda de madrid y/o Puerto de navacerrada y/o Valdeski.

El alquiler de ski de travesía deberá forzosamente realizarse el día antes en una tienda de montaña en Madrid. Citamos a modo de referencia deportes Alaska (C\Cartagena)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

NOTA1 RESPONSABILIDAD: La descripción de la Excursión y el croquis de la misma están disponibles en el repositorio de Entrena a Tope. Por favor leedla con detalle y valorar las posibles dificultades que implica. Se adaptara el ritmo a los participantes siempre dentro de un horario previsto. Al apuntarse, cada uno debe ser consciente de sus propias limitaciones. El organizador del plan, no es un guía. El solo propone y facilita un plan para completar todos juntos. No tiene la responsabilidad de ir en el grupo de cabeza o marcar el ritmo, ni de recuperar y orientar a los rezagados.

NOTA2 CUOTA ASISTENTES: Solo podrán asistir acompañantes si la cuota de asistentes del plan no se ve superada. Las personas inscritas al plan tienen prioridad. Para asegurar que vuestros acompañantes puedan asistir, recomiendo que se apunten al plan. Creo que todos entenderéis, que esto es lo mas justo para todo el mundo.

NOTA3 QUEDADA y DESPLAZAMIENTOS: El Punto de Encuentro 1 está establecido para ir juntos en coche hasta el punto 2. Indicad al apuntaros si iréis al Pto encuentro 1/2 y con/sin coche propio. El organizador cuadrará asistentes y vehículos con suficiente antelación en los comentarios del plan. Los asistentes sin coche que 1ro lo indiquen en un comentario tendrán prioridad sobre las plazas de vehículo. Los asistentes al punto 1 que viajen en el mismo coche compartirán los costes de la gasolina/transporte. Los asistentes al Punto 2 deben proporcionar Tlf contacto.

NOTA4 COMPROMISO ASISTENCIA: Los Organizadores del Grupo se comprometen desde que se crea el plan (con bastante antelación) a la asistencia al mismo. Los asistentes deben apuntarse con la mayor antelación que les sea posible, por respeto a los otros miembros, y a la vez fomentar el éxito de participación en el plan. No es apropiado apuntarse o borrarse de los planes en el último momento o presentarse sin estar apuntado. Cuando surja una contingencia que impida asistir, debemos borrarnos del plan, y tratar de informar al organizador lo antes posible. 

NOTA5 CLIMATOLOGIA: Los planes de EAT se celebran independientemente de las condiciones climáticas; Salvo que las mismas impliquen un riesgo para los participantes. La previsión meteorológica esta disponible con 3-5 días de antelación con cierta probabilidad de fenómenos. En el caso de probabilidad de fenómenos meteorológicos, rogamos no apuntarse a quienes dependan de condiciones climáticas para asistir o no y/o borrarse al menos con esta antelación.

NOTA6 SEGURIDAD PLAN: Los organizadores informarán sobre detalles de seguridad en la redacción del plan. Esto es un grupo de amigos, No es su deber/responsabilidad recordarlo a posteriori, ni asegurarse de la observación de la seguridad entre los asistentes durante las actividades. Por contra los Asistentes, tienen la obligación de informarse por su cuenta, sobre posibles dificultades técnicas y/o moderados riesgos del plan. Debiendo tener en cuenta esto y sus posibilidades personales, para afrontarlas. En cualquier caso, los Organizadores podrán aconsejar a alguna persona la no realización del plan, en el caso de opinen que no está al nivel Físico/Técnico para realizar la actividad sin riesgo personal o grupal. Si el plan tiene algún riesgo aparejado, superior a la actividad diaria. Plan No Exento de Riesgos Personales con la Marca (PNERP) en el Titulo. 

Actividad Outdoor: Se deberá contar con agua, alimentos y con calzado y ropa de abrigo adecuados a la actividad y posibles condiciones meteorológicas. / Bicicleta: Imprescindible contar con Iluminación, Casco e indumentaria adecuada. Las bicicletas deberán tener las condiciones de seguridad adecuadas a la actividad. / Ski, Patinaje: Imprescindible contar con material en condiciones de seguridad. / Actividad de exigencia aeróbica: No se permitirá la participación en estas actividades de personas con problemas cardiovasculares y/o obesidad de 2do grado o superior.

description:
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 3.6 miles round trip
Elevation gain: 590 feet
Difficulty: Easy


Tamanawas Falls forms a broad curtain where Cold Spring Creek thunders over a 150’ lava cliff near the eastern base of Mount Hood. This hike along scenic Cold Spring Creek has been a traditional trek for families.

The hike begins at the Sherwood Trailhead. From the large parking area, walk through the woods toward the roaring East Fork of the Hood River to find the trail, where it crosses the raging stream on a massive, new log bridge (installed in 2007 after floods removed the former bridge). Turn right after crossing the bridge, and follow the East Fork Trail (no. 650) north as it gradually climbs high above the river and highway. At the half-mile mark, pass a viewpoint and round the corner into Cold Spring Creek canyon. The trail drops gently, and soon reaches the East Fork-Tamanawas Falls Trail Junction, where you head straight (left) toward a bridge over Cold Spring Creek. The continuation of the East Fork Trail heads north (right), and is an alternate route to the falls from the Polallie Trailhead.

After crossing the creek, the trail ambles upstream, always within sight of the rushing stream, which tumbles over a series of tiny waterfalls. At 1.5 miles beginning climbing above the creek on a section of new trail. Pass the signed Tamanawas Falls-Tamanawas Falls Tie Trail Junction on the right, and then pass a second unsigned junction for the same trail (#650B). Continue on to Tamanawas Falls, crossing the upper reach of the large rock fall for a quarter mile. Beyond the rock fall, the trail enters forest, and soon arrives at a fine view upstream to Tamanawas Falls, at the 2 mile mark. From here, you can simply enjoy the falls from the trail, or follow one of the use paths for a closer look. Sure-footed hikers can climb the talus to the right of the falls to reach the amphitheater behind the falls.
name: Tamanawas Falls Hike

description:
Ever heard of Kava? It's a psychoactive South Pacific beverage made from the roots of Piper methysticum (a member of the pepper family). The taste is allegedly similar to coffee but is also known to create a bit of "buzz". Let's find out together!

MeloMelo (http://melomelokavabar.com/) in Berkeley is the Bay Area's very first kava bar. We will be doing a tasting of various kava items for the evening and chilling (on what will most likely be a liquor filled evening for the rest of the world :-)

Will provide more details on cost for the tasting once I've locked us in.
name: Yes...An Alcohol Free St. Patty's Day!

group.name: East Bay Adventures for Friendly People Over 40

description:
The hike will end later in the evening before sundown for Sunset colors. Bring a headlamp as a precaution.



Start point: Catherine Creek Trailhead
End point: Coyote Wall Viewpoint
Hike Type: Out and Back
Distance: 8.2 miles
Elevation gain: 1750 feet
Difficulty: Moderate

This hike links the Catherine Creek area with the Coyote Wall area. There are great views of the Columbia River, the east end of the Columbia River Gorge, Mount Hood, and a lot of wildflowers.

From the Catherine Creek Trailhead, there are two closed roads that go up from the parking area. For this hike, avoid Road 15, that goes left (northwest). Instead, follow Road 20 that goes right (northeast). The road soon drops down to Catherine Creek as it bubbles through a small oak forest.

About a quarter mile from the trailhead, near the creek, there's a road junction. The most-used path is now Road 21 which crosses Catherine Creek. There is a footbridge for hikers. Just before this, a road goes faintly left. Follow this faint road, which is the continuation of Road 20. Don't cross the creek.

From here, the road goes along the west side of Catherine Creek, a ways above the creek. This road is passable by 4 wheel vehicles, so it makes an easy hiking trail.

By mile 1.5 from the trailhead, when you reach another junction, you've gained 1000 feet of elevation. From here Road 20 goes left (west) out of the Catherine Creek drainage, over towards Coyote Wall and a fainter road continues north.

The trail over to Coyote Wall uses an old 4 wheel drive road grade, which makes it an easy hiking trail, gradually sloped and wide. There are a lot of bicycles that use this. Someone cuts the branches and trees that fall across the road. This is not a solitude hike, but it's far enough from trailheads there aren't too many people. Keep a watch for bicycles that can sneak up behind you and startle you. This trail ends at the Coyote Wall Trail at mile 4.1 from the Catherine Creek Trailhead. Go west to get the splendid views from the basalt rim at the Coyote Wall Viewpoint. Return the way you came or try one of the variations listed below.

At mile 1.7 is the high point of this hike at 1300 feet elevation. At mile 2.1 the trail crosses a stream. At mile 3.2 the trail crosses another stream. You could use these for drinking water, but in the late spring and summer they probably dry up. Between the two streams are several grassy ridges that go up and down from the trail. You can find many flat places you could pitch a tent at. It can get pretty windy here, so you might try to find the most protected place you can find.

Past the second stream, the trail drops 400 feet down to Coyote Wall. There are several private residences above you. We will NOT be hiking the top of Coyote Wall, That is another long Hike Altogether.
name: Catherine Creek to Coyote Wall Hike - AFTERNOON HIKE

description:
We're traveling to amazing Marrakesh, where we'll stay in a traditional Riad, a spacious home built around a central courtyard.  

The Riad is located within the medina, the old center of the city, which is closed to automobile traffic.

We will have three day trips that will take us outside the city... Highlights will include a balloon trip over the foothills of the Atlas mountains, a camel ride, a visit to one of the areas famed casbahs (fortresses).  

Within the the city itself is one of Africa's largest open air markets, opulent palaces and the famed Majorelle Gardens.

Each participant will have their own bedroom.  Breakfast is provided, along with several group dinners, and we will have a cook/housekeeper at our disposal.  Transportation to and from will be provided, though please note $[masked] is a ground only price.  Airfare is not included.
name: 8 Nights in Exotic Marrakesh, Morocco

description:
tough week...tired...no energy...irritable...frustrated.. AND looking for something that WILL change your life...give yoga a chance to transform your life in a really magical way that you could never have imagined before.

CLICK HERE FOR MORE INFO...

TIME: 9:00am - 10:00am

VENUE: Sea Point, Promenade (Opposite Winchester Mansions

COST: R40.00 PER PERSON, PER CLASS (bring cash with on the day to pay)

MAT HIRE: R10.00 PER MAT

What style of yoga is this?

We will be practicing a style of yoga that is called Vinyasa. Vinyasa yoga is a style of yoga that flows from one posture to another...

Vinyasa style yoga starts with a slow warm up that will include Sun Salutations and variations of Sun Salutations. There will be a number of standing, seated and balancing poses during the class. The class will end off with stretching and time in Savasana to rest.

The classes are more than simple stretches, and will challenge you mentally and physically.

When Vinyasa is practiced over a period of time it becomes a very special part of your day. Vinyasa is a moving meditation where each breath is linked to flowing movements and this steady rhythm of breath and movement together, creates a magical calming of the mind.

IMPORTANT TO KNOW...

Anyone, can practice yoga! From the very fit to the very unfit, the very flexibles to the very unflexibles...the very old...and even the very grumpy :-) men and women alike will benefit from yoga!

What to expect?

To do physically challenging postures and movements that will allow you to feel your body come alive.

Anything else?

to get the most out of your practice...and to be respectful of others practising too...please keep the following in mind...

Arrive 10-15 minutes early

Yoga is done without shoes on (so leave them next to your mat or in the car)

Injuries or medical conditions. Please let me know before class

Practice on an empty stomach, but be well hydrated

Dress appropriately, wear something that you feel comfortable in (normal gym clothing is suitable)

Leave all valuables in the car

Turn your cell phone off and forget it exists

Please do no wear any fragrances to class

Please do not leave class early!

Bring water with to drink during class.

FAQ

I don't have a yoga mat? Not to worry, you can hire one on the day for R10.00

What if the weather looks bad? We will cancel the event online should we feel the location is not suitable to practice

Want to know more? visit our blog for more info...
name: Outdoor Yoga @ Organic Union

description:
The Nature of Effective Prayer  is the second class in a four part series exploring the writings of Dr. Ernest Holmes in his now classic book, The Science of Mind.   The class is an active dialogue among spiritual seekers and will include some experiential practices including meditation, affirmation, prayer, chanting and visualization.

The aim of  the teaching of Science of Mind and Heart is to heal our lives of  all discord, fear, superstition, guilt and sense being unworthy of the abundant gifts of Life.  We offer a practical approach to life that incorporates the perspectives of both modern science and spiritual faith.   We teach that wholeness is real, and it can be found at the very center of who and what we are  -  right now. 

There is a tuition cost for this class of $15 per session or $100 if paid in full by Week 3.
name: The Nature of Effective Prayer

description:
One of the benefits of practical philosophy is to give us a deeper understanding of one of the most misunderstood and challenging ideas in many eastern philosophies; non-attachment. Many philosophical and spiritual traditions identify a lack of detachment with the continuous worries and restlessness produced by desire and personal ambitions. This event will provide the opportunity for a thoughtful, respectful and engaging discussion on how aspects of non-attachment can be put into practice in our modern lives. This will be event #22 for our group in Vancouver. 


Please remember to view at least one of the videos on our Food for Thought page prior to the event:

Click here to view the Food for Thought page for this event


Psychology Dinners Event (Sunday March 15)

Many of our Philosophy Dinners members are also members of the Psychology Dinners group in Vancouver. Click here to sign up for the Self-confidence event and click here to view the Food for Thought videos for this event.


As per usual, our discussion facilitators will be provided with thought-provoking questions to fuel the discussions (available soon). Our members take turns facilitating these discussions. As the coordinator for all of our groups around the world, I'm the one who coordinates the facilitators for events prior to the event taking place (with one facilitator for every table of 6 people). I also facilitate events which take place in Vancouver.


If you want to attend this event then RSVP 'Yes' via this web page and follow the instructions to pay the small fee online. Cash payment is not accepted at the door. Click here to read why this is the case.


Why is there a small fee? Click here to read the reasons why there is a small fee to attend our events.



For more information on Philosophy Dinners please visit ourFAQs page and our home page:

philosophydinners.org


Sincerely, 
Glen Brauer 
Founder, Facilitator and Event Coordinator 
http://philosophydinners.org/ 
https://www.facebook.com/groups/philosophydinners
name: Non-attachment (appetizers & discussion)

description:
Check out www.A2Movements.com for detailed info!

  


Bring water, wear sporty attire (long pants & covered shoes + rubber sole

and the waiver form (can be found on website)

Provided below is a detailed guide of "how to get there";Do save the following

The new location is held at Tai Seng. The address is as follows;Oxley bizhub 1, Blk 65 Ubi road 1 #04-27 S[masked])

(Drivers)

1) way one- Entering the building if you can find the ramp up, head to level 4.- Turn right once you exit- Follow the road (your car would across a bridge)- once across, head straight till the lift lobby- you should see a glass door to your left. Exit car & walk down the corridor till you find the "wooden door" (refer pic)

2) way 2- Entering building you head down basement- park & find blk 65 ( yellow colored)- head up either of the lifts- look for the wooden door (see pic), it is right in the middle of the corridor.

(BMW aka Bus Mrt Walk)1) Way one- take mrt to Tai Seng- find exit B- once you see the light of day, turn right & keep walking straight till you are at the traffic light- you should see OXLEY BIZHUB logo on the building diagonally across you. Walk towards it- Refer to below for the rest of the way

2) way 2- if you can only take buses these are the ones you can take to trinity @ paya lebar8, 22, 24, 28, 43, 58, 70m, 70, 76, 80, 158- the building is directly opposite trinity church (so no matter which side you alight. the building - OXYLEY BIZHUB, is opposite the church)- refer to further instructions below

(BMW - part 2)- Entering the grand building up the stairs. Walk straight towards the middle building & find the lift lobby- once you find the lift, ONLY in the middle building. Press level 4 (if there is numbers above 4, you have taken the wrong lift)- exiting the lift (of the middle building) it should take you up to the swimming pool & fitness gym.Turn right!- we are right in the middle of that building you see right in front of you. - find the glass door that leads you to a straight corridor- find the "wooden door" ( refer to pic)

Hope the above has been comprehensive
name: Parkour Training

description:
* Joint event with Toronto Business & Social Network (1,400+ members)

Downtown Afterwork Social Mixer

Free major socializing events in downtown Toronto. We aim at attracting hip, young, and sociable professionals, networkers, and fun lovers, and are establishing a community were members enjoy meeting once a while at a cool/nice venue after work on a week night or during the weekend.

I am hosting a social drinks night for GTA business professionals and entrepreneurs to mingle and connect.

When you enter the venue let one of the bar staff know you are there for the event - ask for Frank.

Our reservation will be at the large lounge couch at the back.

Come out and socialize with other GTA business professionals/entrepreneurs over drinks!

We have over 7 meetup groups invited to this event so this won't be a small crowd.

Remember to bring your business cards as this is a networking event.

This event is FREE to attend, food and drinks are at your own cost.

We will have name tags for everyone and encourage people to mingle.

(Hosted by Frank)

----------------------------------------------------

**********************************************

----------------------------------------------------

Afterwork Business & Social Networking (ABSN)

Venue: Downtown Toronto (near Bloor & Yonge usually)

Networking, sharing, learning, peer-assisting, getting clients, recruiting team members... Expand your circle and horizon.

You get to ask questions from experts, find potential team members, be inspired by others' startups, test and get feedback on your projects or million-dollar ideas... Lots of smart or well-connected people with diverse expertise and experience in this network--come trying it out!

More details can be found near the end of this event description.

* You are welcome to PM the Co-Organizers if you have any suggestions, ideas, or like to volunteer/Co-Host an event. Together we'll make this series of events better along the way, and shape it to a format that maximizes the benefits to your needs and the community as a whole.

EPI-Networking is a series of networking events focusing on a particular expertise or topic, such as social media, mobile apps, business, 3D printing, wearable technologies, Internet of things (IoT), investors, accelerator programs, marketing & branding, e-commerce, etc. Attendees will have the opportunity to mix and mingle, share their experience, connections, opportunities, and advance their knowledge, skills, career, or business.

* EPI-Net stands for Entrepreneurs, Professionals & Investors Network

Join Toronto Entrepreneurs (5,000+ members) for ALL EPI-Networking events, entrepreneurship-related meetups as well as pointers to tech, professional, and business events.

Hosting EPI-Net groups for this ABSN event:

* Toronto Business & Social Network (1,400+ members)

• Toronto Young Professionals & Entrepreneurs (1,250+ members)

* Please check for updates/instructions or make comments at one of the above groups (as this is a joint event across many groups).

* Volunteers wanted: If you can help co-host this series of events, it is highly visible within the Dream-BIG community (30,000+ members in Toronto) and will help build yourself up as a go-to-expert. I'll see whether I can get the venue owner to sponsor co-hosts/organizers a beer/wine or something. Email me at [masked] if interested. Suggestions welcome.

---------------------------------------------------

Event Details:

This coming event is targeting at business owners, professionals, startups, as well as anyone who likes to use their service or simply to meet and consult them about some questions during the gathering.

Attendees get to share/exchange their expertise and cutting-edge knowledge or service in this area. If you have a product, idea, or startup and like to know the professional opinions about it, welcome to bring it along to the meeting and brainstorm with interested attendees.

I'll connect and match people (for FREE). If you are relatively shy or new to the meetup community and don't know where to start, we will also do what we can to help you fit in. Every attendee is encouraged to help each other out this way or in your own creative way--we are a peer-assistance community and we will all eventually benefit from giving and lending a helping hand...

If this meetup interests you, you may also want to join the following EPI-Net Circle

Toronto Business & Wealth Circle

* Everything is FREE there.
name: Downtown Afterwork Social Mixer & Business Networking (FREE !)
